remixed_from.author: Vaniac
remixed_from.title: AM8 Electronics Case Lid Remix 120mm Fan

title: AM8 Reworked Electronics Case For RAMPS 1.4, Dual MOSFET & Fan

description.text:
A heavily reworked AM8 electronics case, designed to fit a RAMPS 1.4 board, two MOSFETs and a 120mm fan.

Features:

  • Mountable on the AM8 frame using 5 regular M5*10 screws.
  • Houses a RAMPS 1.4 board, uses 3 mounting holes.
  • High enough to house a full graphics display adapter and TMC stepper drivers.
  • Houses two MOSFETs, one for the hotbed, one for the hot end.
  • The lid allows you to mount a 120mm fan. The X motor needs to be rotated on the other side of the X holder to make room for it.

WARNING: The fan needs to have a bit of a dent to allow access to the lid screw hole. Check the 3rd picture. If your fan doesn't have a dent, you will have to grind off a bit of material from it. I plan fixing this in a future version.

Assembly:

  1. Mount the case on the AM8 first using 5 regular M5*10 screws.
  2. Mount the Arduino Mega 2560 into the case. Use 3 M3*10 screws and 3 printable spacers included in this thing.
  3. Mount the RAMPS 1.4 board and all modules you want onto the Arduino afterwards.
  4. Mount the two MOSFETs using a total of 8 screws usually used for screwing in optical drives in a PC. M3 should work as well.
  5. Install the 120mm fan on the lid. Use 4 M4*35 screws with countersunk heads. Please refer to the fan warning above.
  6. Install the lid on the case using a single M3 nut inserted into the case part and an M3*10 screw on the lid.

There is still room for improvements. If you notice anything that you would improve, or if you have a suggestion, please let me know!

As usual, I am including the Blender source file in case you want to edit it.

Dial para caja fuerte

3" impeller for GY6 50 supercharger.

I initially planned on investment casting this part, but manufacturing and post processing would be expensive(both time-consuming and financially) However, because plastics in general are roughly a third of the weight of aluminum the part can be made more robust without incurring weight penalties...this coupled with an "enclosed vane" design add to the strength of the part.

The original prototype in PLA was very promising. After the design is more finalized I plan on trying this part in PC-ABS for both better strength and the ability to smooth the shallow angle layer lines insides the channels.

Although the amount of boost this engine can handle(given Its relatively high compression ratio of 10.5:1 ~ 3-4PSI) is very limited I thought it would be a neat project.

The GY6 150 has a much tamer CR of 8.8:1 ~ 6-7+PSI...That one will be way cooler but will require about a 41% increase in impeller tip speed. [learn to wak before you run, lol]

The SolidWorks file is a mess...I thrive in chaos. ;)

comments.text: If there's a project you're working on...I'll help. It's not just scaling...strike that. You're on your own. I'm technically not an engineer. And won't to be one.

title: USB 4" Desk Fan to Pedestal Fan Conversion

description.text:
This thing converts a 4" USB Desk Fan into a small Pedestal Fan, ideal to raise it higher off the desk. It's possible to tilt the fan up/down to direct the air, as with the original frame.

It's designed to suit the "Daffodil UFN100" like this one:
https://idaffodil.co.uk/usb-desk-fan-daffodil-ufn100-black.html
http://amzn.eu/de2Quf4
These are different brand names but look the same:
http://amzn.eu/8MUlU35
http://amzn.eu/aPwnPTU
http://amzn.eu/3pEyPIr
http://cpc.farnell.com/pro-elec/pel00858/usb-desk-fan-mini-4/dp/HG00868
These fans seem ubiquitous on the Internet and in the High Street.

There are only 3 parts to print (base, arm, and clamp), and you need to print 2 of each, then bolt them together with M3 screws. The picture shows how it goes together. This prints easily on small beds, and individual parts could be replaced if they break. Minimal support is needed to print the arms, but everything else prints without.

The assembled base shown in the photos has 120mm span and seems pretty stable. If you want a bigger base, I've also uploaded an alternative version "fan_base_150mm.stl" which has 150mm span when assembled.

Update: 13/02/18 - added an optional "big foot" which is designed to slot on the ends of the base. This will accept a large nut for a bit of weight, and suits 24mm diameter by 4mm thick foam/rubber feet like these: http://www.wilko.com/all-hardware/wilko-foam-floor-protector-multi-24pk/invt/0344743

Other hardware needed:

  • 8x8 Aluminium U section, or box section (cut to your preferred length)
  • 4x M3x20 screws for the top clamp
  • 4x M3x10 screws for the base clamp
  • 2x M4x20 screws to mount the fan
  • The two rubber washers off the original fan

Sticking rubber feet on the end of the four legs will greatly improve stability. The U channel allows the cable to be neatly routed down the pedestal. The wire can be secured in the channel with velcro ties or cable ties.

The U channel was a 1m length from a local DIY store (B&Q probably) and the label says "FFA Concept 2005.5266". The external dimensions are 8x8mm and the aluminium thickness is 1mm.

The SketchUp model is included for ease of editing.

description.text:
A right side cable chain for your AM8 hotbed!

Features:

  • Designed for the right side. This helps to prevent the hot end from running into the chain.
  • The frame side of the chain is mounted by replacing the original AM8 T underside bracket.
  • Comes with the regular sized frame mount, and with one that is offset by 11 mm. If you have a regular AM8, use the regular one. If you are using my Anet A8 Ultimate Direct E3D v6 & Titan Extruder Carriage With Chain, use the 11 mm one to compensate for the required hotbed offset.
  • The chain needs a total of 16 links, but print more to have a bit extra. Your link count might differ if you have a different AM8 setup than myself (mine is offset further backwards).
  • The hotbed side is mounted on the Anet A8 carriage using three M4 screws and nuts. It is currently mountable only on the original carriage, but I am working on adding the one-piece version as well.

As usual, I am including the Blender source file in case you want to edit it.

Plenum for GY6 50 supercharger.

This design is going to get a major rework. The redesign of the supercharger itself has freed up lots of room for the intake tract, proper and the coupling sizes and locations have changed.

The volume is correct and overall design worked well with the initial prototype but it needs an overhaul. Like several of the parts, I had planned on making a pattern and core box for green sand casting (I still might). But the idea of printing this in a flex/semi-flex material means that the "hose" couplings (and pitot tube support??) could be integrated and simplify the build.

Like most of this project, it's a work-in-progress.

comments.text: With using 3D printed things in fluid mechanics class, we found that 3D printed parts could not be trusted to be waterproof even when the pressure were only that across a venturi pressure drop test piece. How do you plan on ensuring an air-tight design of a plenum chamber, which are usually under pressure?

description.text:
X axis holders, designed with AM8 in mind, but compatible with the original Anet A8 as well!

Features:

  • Designed for AM8, but almost identical to the original Anet A8 X axis holders, so they should be backwards compatible.
  • Smooth rods sit a bit deeper in than the original. Keep this in mind when using an X tensioner, as you will need longer screws.
  • Compatible with the following X tensioner: ANET A8 X- axis belt Tensioner (x- Achsen Riemenspanner) M4, but you will probably need longer screws.
  • X endstop similar to the original Anet A8.
  • I suggest using LM8LUU type linear bearings to decrease Z wobble.
  • Installation more/less identical to the original, but with easier smooth rod insertion, provided that your printer is within good tolerances.

As usual, I am including the Blender source file in case you want to edit it.

print_settings.Notes:: If you plan on using construction ABS cement to connect this to your 3" ABS pipe, you will need to print wider outer layers. The cement will melt through a simple 2 layer outer and possibly make a big mess of your project. I would go with 4 outer layers, at least.
print_settings.Printer:: R1 ABS + PLA Model

title: 3 Inch ABS to 3 Inch Flex Tube Adapter

description.text:
This is an adapter for a 3" ABS Pipe to a 3" dryer duct (aluminum or spring material). It is part of a larger project that I'm working on for a DIY temperature-controlled heated build chamber. See the details in the "How I Designed This" section below, and stay tuned for updates.

The end that inserts into the 3" ABS pipe has a 0.5% draft angle on both surfaces, allowing it to easily line up with the pipe and then get progressively tighter. If you are using this adapter for airflow, the draft angle allows the adapter to be used with or without ABS cement.

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 ABS + PLA Model

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Med or High

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Support is not needed if you print with the small side down and print with attached skirts (offset = 0.00mm). I used a width of 4 and two layers to make sure it stayed adhered to the bed.

If you plan on using construction ABS cement to connect this to your 3" ABS pipe, you will need to print wider outer layers. The cement will melt through a simple 2 layer outer and possibly make a big mess of your project. I would go with 4 outer layers, at least.

Part of a Larger Heated Enclosure/Filtering Project

I am planning on creating a short 3 inch heater element to go into the path of the same duct and connected to a PWM heater control to create a fully controllable chamber heating system. This 3" ABS will house the heater. I've been experimenting with the core from a hair dryer, with all the protections left in place (thermal switch, thermistor, outer covers), and driving it with a 24v power supply at about 2A. It heats the air nicely and since the air is recirculated back into the chamber, the heat will be additive and I don't need to run the coils that hot.

For intake, I am using Donzi's "Active Carbon and Hepa Filter assembly set" (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1764408) with my "80mm Fan to 3 in Tube Adapter" (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2740506) to adapt directly to the 3" flex tube.

I will write this entire project up as a separate Thing once I finish all the PWM and Temp Sensor electronics.

title: Prusa i3 MK3 PINDA sensor protector

description.text:
My first thing that I publish publicly.

Prusa used to offer an official PINDA sensor protector as an STL for the MK2. Since the extruder design on the MK3 is completely different there is not enough space anymore to fit the old protector.

To protect the PINDA sensor from rogue/lifting prints (Nefertiti nearly killed my PINDA if I had not aborted the print), I started Fusion360 and designed my own PINDA sensor protector for the MK3.

Make sure to dial in your extruder multiplier correctly and best use ABS or PETG for printing. I have still printed it only in PLA - and that seems to be fine from a temperature point of view (while printing PLA:-))

Supports:

No

Notes:

I have printed it with 0.15mm layer hight and it goes on perfectly. Place the flat end on the bed!

title: Coffee Dispenser for Nescafé glass bottle
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Tired of filthy spoons in the coffee jar? Tired of coffee abstinence making your hand shake and coffee going everywhere but in your coffee mug? Fear not! The coffee dispenser is here to help. Just place it over your cup and turn 1/2 way for 1 teaspoon of coffee (5ml). Turn again if you want more, easy!

No spare parts required. Everything can be printed (except the nescafe glass containter).
The Nescafé container that this print is designed for, has a inner diameter of 46.6mm. See photos.

Print instructions:
Print two DosierFasteners. One of each of the other stl files.
Use supports on top and bottom.
I printed using 0.2mm layer height on a prusa i3 mk2s.

Assembly instructions:
See video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tqcsF8uFTTg
IMPORTANT: Note that the hole in the top part and the hole in the limiter should be on opposite sides. Otherwise you might just pour the whole bottle directly into your coffee cup. Adjust their relative position to each other by changing the pin's position in the top part. The limiter all ways need to be screwed on as tight as possible without braking the print.

  • You might want to try the screws into the doser, before you do the assembly. it just goes smoother the second time you screw and makes for more easy assembling.
  • You might want to take the foam from inside the nescafé lid, make some cuts and put it into the top part. That will make the top part more airtight and make the top fit nicer to the nescafé bottle. This is optional though.

Usage instructions:
Position the nescafé bottle over your mug. Turn the bottom part half a turn and coffee should be dosed.

Check out other useful prints over at www.youtube.com/ttgeek

I've been working on this design for 3 days now, so i'd appreciate a coin or two if you find it useful. Thanks!

description.text:
This filament spool holder is made for the IKEA Stuva corpus. (http://geni.us/IKEAstuva)*

I'm using this IKEA Stuva cubicle for my Anet A6/ A8 printer. It fits very good in the housing.

The spool holder will be clamped on the top plate of the cubicle an can be fixed by screws from the back.
In the standard version, both sides have the same size of the roll. Later I created an extra wide version for different spool sizes. The spools width from different suppliers differ, therefore it helps to make these compatible.

I used thoose ABEC-9 608 WHEEL BEARINGS for a silent rotation of the spool. (http://geni.us/BM2iYyb)*

For each roll, you need the spacer in the STL files.

For the assembling I used following parts:

4x M4 x 25 screws
4x M4 nuts

My Recommendation: Press the ball valve in the roll directly after finishing the print. It's easier while it's warm. Before shrinkage!

description.text: I received a loose coil of filament from Proto Pasta thinking that I could just lay it on the spool holder of my printer. I was wrong! That lead to a desperate search for a solution. I found the Faberdashery Spool by FablabMoebius and the remix by tschaboo. I started with the remix because it promised to use much less filament. I printed the two sides and three forks but when I tried to put the spool together I found that the inside diameter of my coil was much smaller than required based on the dimensions of the forks... I didn't want to take the time for a reimplementation so I took the fork STL files to Tinkercad and cut out some material. The arms of the fork are also very long (too long for my printer) so I chopped part of them off as well. It was a quick and dirty job and that's what I got. It turns out that I had cut too much out of the internal dimensions of the fork but I didn't want to take the time and filament to modify my changes in Tinkercad and reprint all three. Instead I created a simple spacer to fit on each fork. In the end it worked, mostly. I should have cut the arms even a bit shorter so the spool would spin properly on my existing spool holder but I was in a hurry to print with the filament. Bottom line is that this is a hack job but might be a flexible design for me going forward as I receive loose coils with different internal diameters.

description.text:
I designed this style of sma mount about 4 months back and have been adapting the same thing to many other frames like the xbee x v2, my own viper frame and a few others. Allows for the antenna to be at best angle so you don't clip any gates, get hung up on a branch, etc. Also since it's tpu it allows the antenna and sma to flex during a crash to prevent your vtx from getting torn up or your antenna also.

I've named this antenna mount type "hitcher style" because it reminds me of how they have their thumbs out when the sma is mounted :)

title: Hard Disk Turntable for 3D scanning (non-motorized)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text: I'm futurejames and I have a hoarding problem.  Namely, hard drives.  Just can't seem to throw them away.  I also needed a turntable for some 3d scanning -- nothing automatic just something I could turn by hand.

• Rip apart hard drive. Remove the innards (platters), but leave the bearing inside and the tall center hub (in some drives you don't have a choice).
  • Print out this platter. It was tricky for me to lift off the painter's tape after. If you don't have anything at hand to make it easier, try swearing at it for lubricant.
  • Carefully put the platter on the center hub. Its going to be an extremely tight fit. I found it easier to put the platter flat on a hard surface and push the drive into it. Be careful to keep it level, its not going to work as a turntable if it wobbles like a broken record player.
  • Remember its not really hoarding if you put it to good use! :D
    • Changed to more restrictive license due to Makerbot legal changes. Sorry!

author: futurejames

description.text: customized with 3D Slash!

DYOR (Do Your Own Robot) es un proyecto organizado por la Universitat Politècnica de València (UPV) con el propósito de ser implementado como una actividad dentro del currículum de Secundaria, Formación Profesional y talleres de robótica, pero también para ser usado para personas autodidactas capaces de hacer su propio robot y aprender las bases de la Ingeniería.

Se basa en la impresión 3D y en la programación de tarjetas arduino en el entrono de Facilino, sencillo por ser en bloques y mostrando como seria el lenguaje C en arduino.
...
Los materiales necesarios para este proyecto son:
1 Arduino Nano v3.0 y placa de expansión I/O Arduino Nano
1 batería USB (powerbank)
2 micro servos de rotación continua FS90R y ruedas de 60mm
2 micro servos SG90
1 sensor de ultrasonidos (SR-HC04)
1 módulo seguilineas TCRT5000
1 matriz de LEDs 8x8 (max7219)
1 zumbador pasivo (KY-006)
1 módulo bluetooth (HC-06)
1 rueda loca
1 cable USB
1 móvil Android
...
Los esquemas de conexiones están realizados con el programa Fritzing.
...

DYOR ROBOT

Para más información:

-Curso MOOC EdX: https://www.edx.org/course/disena-fabrica-y-programa-tu-propio-upvalenciax-dyor101x

-Portal de formación robot DYOR: http://dyor.roboticafacil.es

-Blog robótica de la UPV: http://robotica.webs.upv.es

-Twitter (@roboticaUPV): https://twitter.com/roboticaUPV

-Facebook (robótica UPV): https://www.facebook.com/roboticaUPV

Programación en Facilino

  • Ver arriba las imágenes de la pantalla de los bloques de programación.

  • Programa para el control autónomo del robot ante obstáculos detectados por el sensor de infrarrojos.

  • Pantalla de "Bloques" del programa diferenciada en varias partes:
    • La primera parte (Inicio) dedicada a la inicialización de las variables de los infrarrojos y las pinzas.
    • La segunda parte (Repetir) dedicada a verificar si los infrarrojos detectan algún obstáculo.
      • Si hay un obstáculo:
        • El robot deja de avanzar y se mueve en cualquier otra dirección para salvar el obstáculo.
        • Mueve las pinzas.
        • Dibuja en la pantalla varios círculos, a modo de aviso.
      • Si no hay ningún obstáculo:
        • Se mueve hacia adelante.
        • Dibuja una sonrisa en la pantalla.

Programación en APP Inventor 2

  • Ver arriba las imágenes tanto de la pantalla de diseño como de la pantalla de los bloques de programación.

  • Programa para el control remoto del robot mediante Bluetooth desde una App móvil, con funciones de matriz de LEDs y de movimiento.

  • Pantalla de "Diseño" del programa diferenciada en dos partes:

    • La parte de arriba dedicada a los botones de conexión y desconexión del Bluetooth y de los iconos con las "emociones" que el robot mostrará mediante la matriz de LEDs.
    • La parte de abajo dedicada a los botones que controlan el movimiento del robot.
  • Pantalla de "Bloques" del programa diferenciada en tres grupos:
    • La parte superior y la izquierda dedicada a la inicialización y al control del Bluetooth.
    • La parte de la derecha dedicada al control de los movimientos.
    • La parte de abajo dedicada a los comandos de las "emociones" del robot..

I really would love to love this design, it's something I could see myself using however [BRUTALLY HONEST FEEDBACK ALERT]:
It's really not designed well for 3D printing, the first layer isn't even level. I feel like some description should be added as to how it was designed, the program used, the methods used, supports required, materials best suited for, etc. was it a 3D scan? It appears to be quite fragmented and low poly, which is alright if that is the desired effect, but may lead to extreme structural degradation. I'll see if I can use the base model and clean it up a little bit or re-design it in Fusion 360 when I have some spare time.
This is in no way a personal attack, and feel free to PM me if you'd like to discuss it privately or would like me to remove this comment.

author: oleeskildsen

description.text:
My son wanted a lock from his notebook. So being the awesome dad that I am, I designed this.

Should be no issue printing these parts in your favourite filament at your favourite settings. I printed in PLA @ 0.2mm layer height. You'll need 4x Outside Corner and 2x each of the Spine Corner and Spine Corner mirrored. I have also included models for the Side Flap to cover book thicknesses from 5mm to 20mm outside cover to outside cover.

Assembly of the BackPlate, Side and Top Flaps is acheived by cutting a piece of paperclip (0.8 wire diameter) to length and pushing it through the hinges. You may need some pliers to help push it through (and to cut it obviously).

A couple of things to point out: You will likely need to clean up the underside of the bridged section on the Front Plate to allow the Lock to pass through. I did this just by triming the sagging layer with a blade. Some support may prevent sagging. Also worth taking care of the orientation when printnig the corners so that the fill angle of the layer matches nicely in each corner - I have one corner that is at 90° to the rest.

CA glue to attach them to your book of choice.

Lock can also be stored back in the Front Plate when the book is open.

description.text:
This is a housing for a cheap and cheerful thermostat named HW-557.

I modeled this housing using this dummy board: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2483210

As can be seen on the pictures the buttons seem to be offset, so this is work in progress as I might update the design to correct this..

Please note that the holes for the bolts are closed. This allows one to choose how the housing will be mounted/assembled. Drill them to your liking. All cables are supposed to go through a cutout in the back of the housing, including the temperature sensor leads.

EDIT: new print looks better, but the switches are still offset. This can be mitigated by re-drilling the holes on the electronics and on the printed housing - see picture.

EDIT2: ver. B features a flange for better centering of the two prints. The top print is also scaled to 101% for easy assembly. The holes were moved 0.5 mm down and to the right. Also increased the hole diameter.

EDIT3: version C is the same as version B except for the to marked buttons. Not that it was really needed, but I decided to have some fun.

description.text: I bought some small pliers with large grips for use with my 3D printer.  They never fit in any of the tool holders.  So I thought I'd put my new found OpenSCAD skills to work!

description.header: Update July 27 2012: I accidentally uploaded an older version of the file.  I have a more updated one uploaded, this one should do the union correctly.
description.text:
Download the scad file.
Load it up in OpenSCAD (available for Windows Mac and Linux).
Change the variables to whatever you like, you can change:
  • How many tools it holds.

description.text:
Often herd in the background of horror, thriller, and suspenseful scenes in many movies the Waterphone, Mbira, and Nail Violin have haunted many a nightmare over the years. Now it is your turn to return the favor.  
Waterphone, sometime called a water harp. has a fluid sound as it name implies because it has a small amount of water in its basin that resonates with the hammer, pluck, or vibration of its many pins.   
Thee Array Mbira is played much like a piano or xylophone and can have a high pitch humm or a vary low bass rumble. and it many keys gives it great range of the sounds in-between.  
Last but not least the Nail Violin, played with a Bow this fingernail on chalk board sounding screech box can be as beautiful a sound as a bird on a sunny day, or as gruff as and angry teacher.

Waterphone, Print the top and bottom sections. You will then need to make 72 pins each of different lengths out of 11swg steel wire. see this chart for sizes of pins  
[ incomming chart ]  
To play the Waterphone you can pluck it with your finger strum it with a mallet or use a Bow to vibrate many tines at once,  
Array Mbira, Print all the parts, b4 assembly you have the option of adding a internal spring for some added sound adjustment you need a 12mm diameter spring of around 90mm. finish assembly with 4, 4mm pins glued into each corner. you may want to seal the edge also. you will then need 24 m2.5 x 5mm socket head screws. Next you can ither print the fingers or make your own metal ones by hammering a pice of 12swg wire a little flat and giving it a slight curve. You can tune each pin by moving it in the mounting plate. see chart for key layout  
[another chart link]  
How to play, just pluck the ends of the tines with the tip of you fingers or with a small rubber mallet.  
Nail Violin, Print the top and bottom, assemble with 4 4mm pins glued into each corner. you may want ot seal the edge also with some superglue or abs glue. Next find your nails you will need 1/8in diameter nails. about 4in long to start with. you need to trim up the nails to get the tones right then with a little heat or glue incert them into the corisponding hole.  
[chart number 3]  
Play with a Bow or small rubber mallet. it is possible to pluck with fingers but this is kinda difficult to do. with a larger nail size one such as this.

title: K40 Laser Cutter Air Assist Nozzle with Laser Diode Mounts

description.text:
This is an Air Assist nozzle for the K40 Laser cutter which has 2 mount points for 6mm laser diodes.

The diodes are mounted on articulated mounts which attach to the nozzle by means of an M3x10 screw through the nozzle and the diode mount. I'm using zip-ties to secure the laser diodes to the mounts for testing. I'll be drawing power from the LED lighting strip connector, through a 5V power regulator (3.3V would be better) with the laser diodes running whenever the LED lighting is on.

The use for this is to set a workpiece in the clamp on the standard bed, test-fire the laser, cutter, and then adjust the mounts for the laser diodes until both red spots overlap on the burn mark the laser cutter has just made.

This gives you both a visible indication of where the cutter will be cutting next, but also allows you to know when the workpiece is at the focal point of the laser - the initial calibration above will target both red dots so they overlap when the surface of the workpiece is at the distance from the laser head that it's meant to be.

The air feed is via the hole in the side of the nozzle halfway between the diode mounts - this is sized to take standard 6mm aquarium air hose fittings.

print_settings.Notes:: Set your wall thickness to 1.5mm (or set infill to 100%) to make sure there is enough plastic in the bosses for the inserts to grab onto.

description.text: I modified DaveGun's original mount to enable the use of threaded inserts. This allowed me to glue the mount flush to my acrylic panel without worrying about fasteners on the backside. I used 6-32 heat set threaded inserts from McMaster-Carr (PN 93365A132) because that's the smallest size I had on hand, but the holes in the perma-proto board are actually slightly smaller than a #6 screw so I drilled them out to 1/8". The brass inserts could short a couple of columns, so you might want to use kapton tape or a nylon washer. I didn't have any problem with shorting.

Printer:

Monoprice Mini Select v1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

See notes

Notes:

Set your wall thickness to 1.5mm (or set infill to 100%) to make sure there is enough plastic in the bosses for the inserts to grab onto.

Use your soldering iron (about 370C worked for me) to sink the inserts into the plastic. Then trim or file the squeezed out plastic.

Technically, you should use a tapered reamer on the hole to get an ideal profile for the inserts. I have a tapered reamer, so I did this, but I don't think it's really necessary. If you don't taper the hole you will probably get excess displaced melted plastic when you push in the inserts.

I wanted a proton pack so I drew one up :D

I used Stefan Otto's plans http://www.gbfans.com/wiki/Stefan_Otto%27s_Prop_Plans
and used the motherboard drill sheet from tgoacher for the mount spots. https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1093376

The cylotron is ment to be bolted to and held in place by the bumper so you can remove it easily for electronics.

This is still a bit of a work in progress. Everything here will print and fit together as it should but nothing is cut for any particular bed size.

The gearbox knob, the booster "ladder" and the Clippard valve are not here. I used the ones from DancinFool82 https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1128019

Any questions please feel free to ask. :)

1-4-18
Added a hollowed out N Filter base. "N filter hollow". Inner diameter is the same as the top. Also for the top half, if you want to open the holes up, a 1/2 inch drill will be what you need. I left the holes closed as I found I get a bit nicer finished hole drilling them after.

1-11-18
Added a shorter cylotron LED option to hold adafruit neopixels. Cylotron LED Short, and cylotron LED Neo. The two parts snug fit together. LED Neo has a short recess in the bottom for the neopixel to snap into.

1-12-18
Made a slight adjustment to "Crank gen 2" Made the hole for the loom a bit larger. Also some minor tweaks on the holes on the synch disk.

1-14-18
Made some adjustments to the left and right bumper mount blocks. Made them a little taller to fit a bit better in the cylotron mount and added recesses for nuts.

1-16-18
Added a cutout cylotron and cylotron cover to fit with the hollowed N filter.

1-25-18
Shortened the legris fitting a bit and tweaked the EDA box to fit against the crank gen a little better. Also adjusted the loom hole in the fill tube. Turns out the 3/4" loom I had here wasn't actually 3/4".

2-2-18
Added a bumper and bumper spacer. Added lenses for the power cell and cylotron LEDs to be printed in transparent filament. Minor update on the HGA, adjusted the sizing on the fitting and bolt holes. Also thinned out the spacer details 1x10, 2x1 and 5x1.

description.text:
Liked the original very much, but wanted something more so here is my version.

This remix is intended to be a hidden mount where you just slide the pegboard over.

I included two versions of the top mount, one for a single board (or outer edge) and one for two boards.

And one lower mount, which just really are a small distance piece to make the board level with the wall.

This is maybe not for those of you with severe ocd since its not that easy to get it nice and straight on the wall but it works well enough for me :)

Creality CR-10S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.20

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I'm far from a pro so you might do this better than me :) I printed it sideways as in the pictures.
Don't really know how much infill is needed, I printed with 20% but used thicker walls so that the part where the screw goes becomes solid.

The double mount is a little prone to tipping so using a brim or a small raft helps, I also used a little support for that one, 80 degrees or so, so it only fills the gap and not the screw hole.

title: Tevo Tornado Octoprint Controlled LED Light Bar

description.text:
LED light bar for the Tevo Tornado. Designed to be controlled by gcode commands. I have uploaded STL files to build a full or half configuration of the light.

To build the light you will need a soldering kit! and have basic knowledge of electrical wiring. I attached a picture of a basic electrical circuit you will need to build/assemble to power/control the light.

I used the custom control plugin for octoprint to make a quick access on/off button (https://plugins.octoprint.org/plugins/customControl/)
G-code Terminal Commands: (On - M42P69S255) & (Off - M42P69S0)

Supplies you will need:
LED light strip i used (https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00HSF66JO/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1)
24v to 12v converter - i used (https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01LY4RANA/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s01?ie=UTF8&psc=1)
Mosfit - i used (RFP30N06LE)
Wire - i used (#22 gauge solid, insulated copper wire)

the rail clamp is threaded to work with the screw i designed. it will be very snug at first when you put the screws in. i recommend screwing them on and off a few times to break-in the threads.

For the Full version you need to print:
2 - light bar
2 - full top bracket
2 - full rail clamp
4 - screw

For the Half version you need to print:
2 - light bar
2 - half top bracket
1 - Left Rail Clamp
1 - Right Rail Clamp
4 - screw

Printer:

Tevo Tornado

Resolution:

.15

Infill:

20%

First thing you will need to do is unplug your machine and open up the control box. Be careful not to pull hard on any wires, you don't want to damage anything. Unplug the 2 big black cables that are connected to the screen and set them to the side the will get in your way,

  • locate the A15 pins.
  • locate the 24 Volt power
  • remove 2 bolts on heated bed power control box and move it to the side. you will be reposining it for this light mod.
  • install 24v to 12v converter box (I used a hot glue gun)
  • attach 4 wires to 24v to 12v converter box
  • drill hole to reposition heated bed power control box
  • attach heated bed power control box
  • wire circuit like in wiring diagram
  • put mosfit in box if you want (i filled mine with hot glue to insulate wires)
  • attach mosfit to side of box (i put mine by one of the fans)
  • reconnect screen cables
  • put control box back together
  • your done!

title: Assistive Technology Mouse (ATMouse)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This device is intended to be an assistive technology solution for computer users whom due to disability or physical condition find it difficult to use a regular mouse but are still able to push buttons. Users with Parkinson's disease, any tremor related condition, cerebral palsy and many other conditions that interfere with the users' ability to make precise hand movements.

The device is based on the Arduino Pro Micro (Leonardo compatible) and thus is a plug and play input device, meaning that it will be recognized as a USB mouse without the need of any additional drivers.

The device has a total of 13 buttons and 3 LED lights. The user can press buttons to:

  • Move the mouse pointer (up, down, left, right)
  • Left click
  • Double left click
  • Right click
  • Hold left click
  • Middle button click
  • Hold middle button click
  • Scroll wheel (up and down)
  • Change the mouse movement speed between 3 different settings.

Also available in GitHub: https://github.com/lowendguru/atmouse

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Resolution:

0.25

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Lower resolution will work just fine.

Instructions

Print the 3 plastic parts (front case, back case, buttons array).
Etch or mill the PCB. This is a single sided PCB board and the tracks only use the "bottom" layer. Ignore the "top" layer of the Eagle design, but use wire jumpers to make the connections seen in the "top" layers.
Solder all electrical components to the PCB according to the Eagle design.
Upload the .ino sketch to the Pro Mini using Arduino IDE (Leonardo board settings).

Assemble the device. Start by placing the cover facing down on a table.
Then put the buttons array inside the sockets.
Make sure the USB cable is connected to the Pro Micro. Then place the PCB, the 5mm LEDs will fit inside their sockets and this will align the whole board into the front case.
Finally place the back case to close. You may have to glue the back case (as there are no screw holes in this version).
Optionally, you can use some pieces Polyurethane foam or similar material between the buttons array and the PCB, and also between the PCB and the back case for a tighter fit.

Bill of materials

13 - 6mm push buttons
13 - 10k resistors
3 - 5mm LED
3 - 1k resistors
1 - PCB board 200x150mm (1 sided)
1 - Arduino Pro Micro
1 - Mini-USB cable
1 - Front case (3d printed)
1 - Back case (3d printed)
1 - Buttons array (3d printed)
Some foam rubber, Polyurethane foam or similar material (for a tighter fit)
Some strong glue (no screws yet, sorry)

Demo of working prototype. Commentary is in Spanish.

title: 24/40 Keck Clip - ST/NS Glassware Taper Joint Clip

description.text: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ground_glass_joint#Joint_clips

(ABS) Clip will weaken at temps of 90C and start yielding around 100C. Do not use for suspending large flasks or large assemblies if the clip will be exposed to temps in that range. After applying clip, always give the two joints a tug to make sure the clip has seated properly above the shoulder on the male joint. Print this clip with about 75% infill. If printed with solid infill, the connecting loops are prone to delamination at the apex which will eventually result in the loop splitting entirely. I printed mine @ 150 micron layer height, 5 surface layer, fast speed, no raft.
--

14/20 Keck Clip: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:274395
19/22 Keck Clip: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:275257

I recommend printing with about 75% infill and 4-5 layer surface. When printed solid, some of the connecting loops are prone to cracking at the apex and eventually splitting. I believe having less than solid infill allows the loops to distribute the flexing forces more evenly rather than concentrating at the crest. I haven't noticed any decrease in strength compared to the solid prints

comments.text:
Hey Unotre :) Great Clip! I printed one of these, really good fit!
But I have a huge favor to ask: Would you pretty please make me a 29/32 version? In Austria, and I think in Europe in gerneral, the 29/32 Ground Joint is really common. I think you would do many people a favor by uploading a 29/32 version ;)
comments.author: clydefrog

comments.text: I just replied to your private message but I'll post here too for anyone else who might be wondering. I think you can make this clip work for 29/xx standard taper joints by scaling the model by a factor of 1.2083x or 20.83%. This should turn it into a 29 mm clip instead of 24 mm clip. The first figure in the designation of any ST joint is the major inner diameter of the taper, which is about where the clip clamps around, while the last figure tells you how long that taper extends from that major diameter. I'll try to upload a model eventually but scaling the model should work reasonably well.

description.text:
Description
A Blue PLA lithophane Lampshade depicting Dolphins in an underwater scene taken from a downloaded google photograph.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FpRvZG3G9UM&list=PL093F566F4B7772D6&index=14

Printer:

i3Omega

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

50%

Notes:

the idea was from MakeAlot .
i took notes of all the tips from the comments that various people wrote on MakeAlot,s source page and used all that info to put the print time down to 18 hrs 40 mins ..from 30 +hrs to create a dolphin scene lithophane lampshade for my mother who absolutely loves dolphins !!! she was overjoyed when i turned on the lamp !! ;)

P.S. I did make the shell 4mm deep as the thinner shell let to much light through as i wanted it to look like an underwater scene which had some really dark shadows .. which made it look better , i also used a 5 mm brim just in case the footprint was not enough to stick to the bed .

i was quite impressed with the result thanks for the idea MakeAlot !!

ive now uploaded a short vid showing the whole shade ..

no rafts just used a 5 line rim for more footprint to aid sticking to bed

UPDATE:- ive now uploaded the (repaired files) so no need to use netfab ect ;)

step by step instruction using my settings for this shade,

i measured the circumference of the original shade and made a template in photoshop of that size then found and downloaded the pic from google and used the photoshop template to crop the image in an area that i could easily merge and stitch together leaving no join .. and then de-saturated the colours in the pic ,to turn it black and white , then a little bit more contrast added to bring out whites a bit more and shadows darker .. then upload the cropped image to http://3dp.rocks/lithophane/ , in the 3d rocks software go to settings, , then in model settings adjust the size settings to whatever is good for you ,i chose 400mm to see detail (as you can adjust scale in slicer too) whilst still in the model settings my settings were as follows ..thickness=3mm,Border was =0mm (as i wanted no appearance of join in final model !!) ,Thinnest layer =0.8mm, Vectors per pixel=4mm,Base stand depth =0 ,and slide the curve all the way to 360!! .then in the main window choose ..Outer curve not the solid cylinder ... you now have all the info i had to make your very own 3D lithophane Lampshade
another thing i did was to incorporate a black line top and bottom of main image before uploading to 3dRocks site this was to ensure of a border top and bottom of printed shade (as black would give a thicker line top and bottom for stability)

comments.author: eltero49

comments.text: Eltero49, I believe that yougurt was being very polite in trying to tell you how bad that print looks. Others wouldn't be so polite, so you daring him to do better isn't the correct response. I can see that based on your other makes in your profile, that your printer indeed needs some tuning and calibration, and putting paint on an un-sanded surface that's already that bad just makes it look worse. It is my opinion that you should take his advice, step back and look at your prints objectively. This is a game of tweaks and the ongoing chase for perfection. You need to keep improving every print, and if someone says, 'that isn't a good print' instead of getting defensive, just ask 'how can I improve it?'. Because, that is indeed a bad print, and you can do better. Try tightening your belts to help with the overshoot and sloppy layers, calibrate your esteps and extrusion multiplier so you're not over-extruding, turn down your accel end jerk so you're not ringing so much, and turn down the print speed altogether and try again. Also, maybe some fresh filament, or some better quality stuff at least.

comments.text: Hola, el problema de la calidad de impresion se debe varios factores, uno de ellos es que esto es un prototipo a escala pequeña (demasiado por el modelo que es) y se imprimo a velocidad rapida simplemente para corroborar que todos los archivos y el modelo en si era 100% imprimible.  Obviamente que si lo quisiera realizar mas detallado utilizo 0.15 de capa y reduzco la velocidad, pero tambien hay que ampliar el tamaño (1:1) para apreciar realmente los detalles del modelo.  Tampoco utilize ningun tipo de alisado (cloroformo o acetona) porque vuelvo a repetir... es una pueba.  Desde ya agradezco sus comentarios y seguire trabajando para ir mejorando poco a poco, paso a paso las terminaciones y alizados finales de las piezas.

description.text:
I wanted to wait to upload this model until I could find the file that contains the .pdf of the decals I created for it. I can't find the file, but if I ever do - I will upload it!

Also, I hesitated uploading because my ROBO-3D printer does not handle overlapping volumes well (overlaps print as air gaps), of which this model has many - especially in the nose portion. I simply couldn't find a way past this in the printer software. Perhaps the overlap problem is my fault, since I can't seem to find an easy way to delete the volume overlaps in the "Wings3D" program I used to create the model. Advice, anyone?

Personally, I use a resin boat plastic product called "Marine-Tex" to fill the gaps. It's incredibly useful for this and for filling gaps in other resin cast models.

I now print exclusively in ABS, since the "Plastruct Plastic Weld" glue I use works extremely well with it, and is not very good with PLA. I haven't tried any others...

I included an .stl of the completed model for show only - I recommend against trying to print this version - print the parts and build it!

Finally, I could also have included an assembly sheet, but I thinks it's pretty self-evident how it goes together. The picture shows the completed model, which I am extraordinarily happy with! I made it at 1:350 scale to go with my polar lights enterprise model. Enjoy!

I've found this design to be more effective than the semi-circular and fully circular fan nozzles. This is a re-design of the stock fan nozzle that shipped with the printer. I've removed some unnecessary arcs and curves and opted for a pretty direct reduction to a 2.4mm opening. Since I installed it I've found my prints to be way smoother with more even cooling.

The walls are thin enough for a 100% infill. And I've kept everything to a nice multiplier of my nozzle width (0.4). My printer and filament I'm using are decent enough to span the small-ish overhangs for a smooth print (other than the overhang on the fan housing insert).

print_settings.Notes:: This is a remix of the S280 but everything has been redesigned for better fit and finish.

description.text:
This is a full running iteration of my BBR pancar based loosely around the S280 pan car based on the Serpent S240. A modified design was created by Ivan Martin found here _ http://myprotorc.blogspot.it/?m=1. His design took the S240 and shrunk it down to 102mm wheel base for use along side the Kyosho Mini-z. Ivan shared his files with me so I could modify it for my own personal use which I've uploaded here. My design was made with Tinkercad.

The top plate is connected using the spacers from a stand-off kit found on Amazon. All of the wholes found on the underside of the baseplate are countersunk and I used various length countersunk machine screws listed below. The steering knuckles are stock MR-03 knuckles. The mid-mount motor mount is from the Kyosho Mini-Z LM series and the differential is from PN Racing. The body and nose clip are for the TRP Mosler. The wheels are Kyosho 0 offset alloy wheels. The front lip is a trim to fit or may need to be completely trimmed off for certain bodies. NOTE: The nose clip mounting holes are designed around the PN Racing Carbon Fiber Adapter (CPxxx) http://www.kenonhobby.com/PN-Racing-Mini-Z-Mosler-MT900-Carbon-Fiber-Adapter_p_42798.html. Any adapter should work along with ride height spacers.

description.text:
EDIT 2: I made one for the Airtripper Extruder (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:126778) aswell

EDIT: I republished this Thing just to upload the final version that actually works as it should and added some relating pictures on the way.

This is an Adapter for mounting the stepper motor to the right side of the x axis frame while using a Bowden Setup.

I created this cause i ran into some problems with the original setup when printing in the last third of the build height.

With this adapter the stepper is mounted to the side of the x axis, inspired by the CR 10's design, so its moving along with the z axis height, the pressure in the bowden tube stays the same over the whole print.

My Design is made to fit those two(three) upgrades:

The x-axis tensioner:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1683070
The Bowden motor mount, fit for the anet a8:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2204941
The Airtripper Extruder:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:126778

Just use longer screws to fit the adapter to the x-axis tensioner, two nuts to secure it and two stock m3 screws to screw the motor mount to the adapter, thats it.
For the Airtripper you need bigger screws, not sure what diameter though.

Happy printing ;)

Made it for use with M4 Nuts for better use with the Belt Tensioner.
And changed the position of the Extruder Motor to the Front, so now we can use the actual z height ;) push fit was blocking last 30cm when mounted in the back, now it works. Really.

title: Motorcycle Jacket Sleeve Vent - Breezy Sleeve

description.text:
In 2015 I saw a picture of a sleeve vent somewhere (can't find it any more...), and I thought it was pretty cool, so I jumped on Thingiverse and I found this:

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:747612

So I printed it, used it, and it broke immediately :(. Maybe it was my printer, but I thought it could use some improvement anyway. I quickly learned CAD and remade it, but a lot tougher and a bit bigger. It performs pretty well for me over 70kph. I've taken a set for a lap of the country, and it's still intact. Then winter came and I forgot about it until now. Now, you guys can use it :)

This was one of the first things I ever made in CAD. I'm willing to do a remake if anyone can think of improvements. I'm excited to see any Makes.

Performance depends on the angle that the vent makes with the wind. Turbulence from your bike may have an effect as well. Try both the palm-side and the knuckle-side of your sleeve, or consider adjusting the grip angles.

The gaps in the vents are just a little bit smaller than the types of bees which are local to me. The idea is that they'd get chewed up rather than fly around in your sleeve. Let me know if this works, I've yet to actually hit a bee with one.

PRINTING
Works fine in PLA, should also work in ABS or PETG, but I haven't tried.

Happy riding!

title: Closet Rod, Hanging Rod, Tension Rod, Shower Curtain Rod

description.text:
Print this to make a tube/rod/bar to hang things from.

Sorry about the crappy title. I know it's not in tension and should be called a compression rod, but they're sold as tension rods here.

If you want to hang heavier objects, you'll need a tougher tube. The end components are quite robust, so depending on your print method, length and tube; you might be able to get away with up to 30kg. Test and adjust.

You want a tube that's not going to flex easily. If the tube bends, the feet move inwards and it doesn't work!

You'll need to either find a rod or tube with 20mm OD, or use a rod of different size and apply the appropriate scaling factor. You'll need to print all four components. One end of the rod has a left-hand thread, and the other has a right hand thread. This means you can twist on the middle of the rod and push both 'feet' out, holding the rod in place.

I'd suggest printing one of the 'inner' parts first so you can check that it fits onto your tube, then you'll know if you need to scale.

Works well in PETG. The thread is quite coarse, so it should also work in PLA or ABS, but I haven't tested that yet. If you do, let me know!

title: MPSM Fully Adjustable Z Spacer (MP Select Mini)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Fully Adjustable Z Spacer

MP Select Mini

By Wiley Kyoto

This Z spacer is designed to give you continuous adjustment from 1mm to 5mm. If you want to switch between the stock bed and glass bed, you don't have to adjust your print bed and then re-level it. If the beds already level, just adjust the spacer for the change in height to account for the glass thickness. Also If you change nozzles, the new one might be slightly longer or shorter, so just adjust the Z offset accordingly. I gave the Bracket a slight bend so it keeps constant pressure to hold it firmly in place.

My Print Setup:
  • PLA
  • 210/60C
  • No Supports
  • 0.175mm Layer Height
  • 1.4mm Wall Thickness
  • 1.05mm Top and Bottom Thickness
  • Orientation - Lay the AdjArm and Bracket flat on their sides. Put the AdjDial on one of the flat ends (I had numbers near the top).
Assembly:
  1. Put the AdjDial on the Bracket, in the groove next to the indicator mark, with the numbers closest to the outside edge.
  2. Insert the sloped edge of the AdjArm through the AdjDial, with the threads of the AdjArm facing away from the Bracket.
  3. Keep pressure pushing the AdjArm into the AdjDial as you start to turn the AdjDial clockwise. Keeping in mind that the thread is reversed thread, such that turning the AdjDial clockwise will wind the AdjArm farther in.
  4. Set the AdjDial to roughly the right spot (See Reading the Dial).
  5. Make sure the head position of the printer is a good couple centimetres in the +Z direction, to prevent damage to the Z limit switch.
  6. Insert the assembled spacer through the vertical slot in the back of the printer tower, snapping it into place on the Z Bearing Block(Black Plastic Block with metal rods running vertically through it), which you can see through the vertical slot. You should hear and feel a solid click as it snaps securely into place, pushing forward firmly on the top lever of the spacer should help it snap into place.
  7. Make final adjustments the the AdjDial but homing the printer and checking the fit with a piece of paper under the nozzle.
Reading the Dial:
  • Note - the readings won't have absolute accuracy as it depends on the exact placement of the Z Limit switch, but the relative accuracy should be great.
  • The AdjArm has 4 notches, with numbers 1 to 4 next to them. These represent whole mm steps.
  • The AdjDial has 40 notches, every 4 notches are numbered .0 through .9. These represent decimal mm steps. Each notch is a 0.025mm step.
  • The Bracket has one indicator notch which lines up with the notches on the AdjDial to indicate where to read the setting.
  • When the outside edge of the Bracket is lined up with the first notch(next to the 1) on the AdjArm and the .0 setting on the AdjDial is centred on the indicator notch, the spacer is set to 1.0mm.
  • When the AdjArm is all the way into the AdjDial, and the AdjDial is set to .0, the spacer is set to 5.0mm.
  • The spacer can be set less than 1mm but at some point (around 0.7mm on my printer) the limit switch will slip off the end of the spacer and effectively act as 0mm offset.

comments.text: Cool design.  I made one.  However, the tolerances are SUPER tight.  I had to sand down the threads internally and externally.
comments.author: maze247

comments.text: Might be that your printer is over extruding a little. I didn't have to do any modification after printing. If I recall correctly there's a 0.1mm tolerance on the threaded section. I might be able to post some looser fitting adjustment dials. It should be tight enough that it won't slowly wiggle loose over time.
comments.author: maze247

comments.text: I also had issues with tolerances. I haven't completely dialed in the printer it printed on, but I needed to scale up x and y of the dial 4 or 5% (I don't remember exactly as I printed it a week or so ago). Scaling the whole part would have screwed up the threading. I used a fairly large layer height so that may have played a part, as well.
comments.author: wileykyoto

comments.text: Thanks. and yeah, it's probably the layer height. I'd recommend .175mm it's not that slow and should print better the first time. That being said, scaling x and y is a good method. Keeps the most important aspect (the pitch) the same and basically just adds clearance.
comments.author: meekajr

comments.text: That's true.  I am currently waiting for my glass, as the aluminum bed is raised in the center, and I figure once level, some of my 1st layer issues should resolve themselves.  If not, at least it should make troubleshooting easier.  Impressive part none the less.  It sure beats scouring Thingiverse looking for the right height for 1/8" borosilicate.  Thanks again!
comments.author: wileykyoto

comments.text: Yeah, printing on glass is great! Although my bed was also raised in the middle, which meant it was difficult to get a consistent level on the glass because it would rock side to side. I just very carefully and very slowly bent the bed to be a lot more level and now it works great with or without glass. What you have to consider when try to fix a bent bed is how its bent and you have to apply pressure to reverse it. For instance mine was raised in the middle middle, but was also a little high in the front middle and back middle. This means that it was bowed from side to side, but relatively straight front to back. So I carefully supported the middle right and middle left with both hands, and used my thumbs to apply firm but careful pressure to the middle middle. Then checked it again, I did those about 4 times until it was right. It doesn't take much so be careful and make sure to support the sides correctly. Also be extra careful, it's harder to bend it back up if you go too far.
comments.author: maze247

comments.text: This is great advise.  I had considered mounting the glass with thermal pads to allow for slight deformations in the aluminum plate during the heating and cooling cycle.  Not sure how I'll finally do it, but thank you for sharing your experiences, always learning...

description.text:
This is a 1/10th scale model of the WAC Corporal sounding rocket, designed to fly on standard 18mm model rocket motors.

Additional required materials:

  • CA glue
  • 12 inch diameter parachute
  • 4 feet of Kevlar thread
  • Aluminum foil tape

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

It is recommended to print all rocket components using PETG. All components are able to be printed without support material. The Top Solid layer, Bottom Solid layer, and Perimeter Shell settings were set at 3 with a 30% triangular infill.

Assembly

Early test versions would melt from the motor ejection charge. To remedy this, it is recommended to line the fin can with aluminum foil tape from the end of the motor forward. 4 feet of Kevlar thread is recommended for the shock cord. Tie one end of the shock cord to the integral mount on the inside surface of the fin can. Glue the body section to the fin can with CA glue or another suitable adhesive. Glue the nose shoulder into the nose cone, and tie the free end of the shock cord to the mount on the nose shoulder. Attach the parachute to the shock cord approximately 1 foot behind the nose cone.

Flying

The rocket has been test flown on an Estes C6-5. Other motors may be used, but have not yet been tested.
Place the motor into the retainer, and thread it into the base of the rocket until snug. The spanner wrench or needle-nose pliers may be used to make this easier. Place 3 sheets of loosely packed recovery wadding into the body tube, followed by the folded parachute and nose cone. The rocket is now ready to fly!

improve the Z-Axis stability and make it much easier to get the two parts exactly parallel because they mate nicely together. No more guesswork.

description.text:
This is a PowerPole adapter for the Elecraft KX2 Radio that (optionally) screws to the side of the radio to firmly attach your power cable to the radio and keep narrow gauge wire lengths as short as possible. It protects the power plug, prevents accidental shorting, and keeps the power cord from getting lost - all without interfering with access to any other radio function.

This adapter is designed to be compatible with:

  • the stock KX2 radio
  • radios with custom end panels; and in particular the Side KX end panels
  • the Side KX clear lexan lid
    -any KX2 heat sink
  • the Side KX car mount lexan adapter (see photo)

THIS ADAPTER MAY NOT WORK WITH ANY OTHER 3rd PARTY AFTER-MARKET UPGRADE.

To build the adapter you will need:

  1. Your 3D printed shell
  2. A stock power cord from Elecraft, DigiKey, etc.
  3. An Anderson PowerPole (15amp or 30amp)
  4. A #4 x 3/8" machine screw (sorry, Elecraft does not use metric parts)

Construction Steps:

  1. Cut the power cord to length using the cutting jig 3D printed part.
  2. Separate the 2 wire strands and strip ~5/16" (7mm) of insulation from the ends
  3. Crimp or solder the bare wire ends into the PowerPole center contacts. Crimping is the preferred method if you have access to the proper crimper...
  4. Insert the PowerPole center contacts into the plastic shells. MAKE CERTAIN THAT THE BLACK & WHITE WIRE GOES INTO THE RED SHELL AND THE SOLID BLACK WIRE GOES INTO THE BLACK SHELL. YOU WILL DESTROY YOUR RADIO IF YOU GET THIS STEP WRONG!
  5. Test continuity and polarity. If you don't understand what this means or how to do it; you should probably purchase a pre-assembled unit. (See below.)
  6. Carefully insert the cable and PowerPole assembly into the plastic shell. This is not easy. Tolerances are intentionally tight and you might break a few shells before you get the hang of it. I wedge the PowerPoles part-way into the shell and then insert the barrel plug. Once the barrel-plug is completely in place, I push (forcefully) the PowerPoles into position.

EDIT - 22 Jan, 2018 - In step 5 above, please note the orientation of the Red and Black PowerPole parts. THEY MUST GO IN THE SAME ORIENTATION AS THE PHOTOS! The red and black shells have slightly different dimensions. The fit is tight already, it will never seat well if you get it backwards.

To screw the adapter to the KX2:

  1. Open the radio (as if to change batteries)
  2. Locate the nylon nut and screw closest to the power socket and remove them. You will need to hold the nut with pliers or other tool.
  3. Insert the PowerPole adapter assembly into the power socket and make sure the screw hole on the adapter lines up with the screw hole in the side panel.
  4. Insert the #4-3/8" screw through the adapter and side panel and install the nylon nut.
  5. Reassemble the case.

A completely assembled and tested item can be purchased here: https://stores.ebay.com/n0wlradio

description.text:
I designed this handheld gimbal as a demonstration for kids to learn how gimbals work. Gimbals have been used on sailing ships for centuries. They were used in the Inertial Measurement Units (IMU's) on the Apollo spacecraft to navigate to the Moon and back.

This is a "4 gimbal" design. The additional gimbal avoids "gimble lock" which would occasionally occur using a 3 gimbal design.

If you add a weight or something in the cup, you can move the handle in any direction you want and the cup will remain reasonably level. The faster you move it, the less stable it becomes but it will settle to a level state. Moving it somewhat slowly will yield the best demonstration.

Please post your comments and makes!

Hatchbox Alpha

30%

Notes:

No Supports are needed. You can print this in place and all axis should move freely after printing.

I have tested this print at 100% and 75% scale. I tried 50% scale and although it worked, it didn't spin very nicely. I think if I broke in each axis for a while that it would work but it's pretty fragile at 50%. I'd recommend nothing smaller than 75% scale.

comments.text: Nice design.  Just wishing to say though, that a 4th gimbal per se doesn't do anything to prevent gimbal lock.  For it to work, it should be actively driven (by a sensor + motor system) to maintain a large angle between the roll and yaw axes (that - when coaxial - cause the lock).
comments.author: quasipedia

comments.text: I knew about the mechanically driven 4th gimbal but your hand works too. I first made a 3 gimbal version and it locked up more often than the 4 gimbal version. Either way it's fun to play with. I'll see if I still have the 3 gimbal version in case anyone wants to print it instead.
comments.author: quasipedia

description.text:
I'm currently building a robot arm, and I needed some kind of gear box, to translate the movement of one of the motor by 90 degrees, for the wrist pivot.

I looked for some kind of cheap gear box, but couldn't find anything affordable, so I decided to make my own.

it uses 1/4" shaft and R4-AZZ bearing.I also used 2 x 1/4" collar to prevent the shaft from moving. I made those on my lathe, but they can be bought in any RC hobby shop.

Bevel gears I used have the following specs:

  • Bevel Gear 1.0 Mod 16T, 90° 1:1
    (Ebay item: 152610910246)

Bore was 6mm, but I drilled them to 1/4" and tapped a 6-32 set screw.

Assembly screws are 6-32, and were tapped directly in the plastic.

The spacing between each flange is 70mm, and the installation screw pattern is 24 x 24mm

Have fun and feel free to ask if you have any questions !

print_settings.Notes:: This is the driver side clip, I'm certain that should you need the passenger side clip, a little mirror image in your slicer would take care of it.

description.text:
3D printer to the rescue once again. Two nights ago as I was getting in to my car (2000
Toyota Camry) in the freezing cold, I lifted the handle and nothing happened. Got in
through the passenger side and started home, once home I took a quick look, the door
handle rod had dislodged from handle, fortunately the handle looked intact. Forward to
today, I finally get the door apart and see that the lock rod clip(the yellow thing) is broken
and so the rod won't stay in place.

Although you can get an assortment of the parts for about 5-8 dollars (Dorman Door Lock
Rod Clips 75474), no one has them in stock, so that would mean 3-5 more days of going
through the passenger side to open the driver door from inside. After about 45 minutes of
measuring and designing and then 3 hours of printing, the problem is solved for now. I'll
probably have to have someone else print some in ABS for the summer, but for now the
flexible filament seems to be doing the job.

author: gothfather

title: Betafpv Z1 camera and VTX mount for Beta65/S whoop

description.text:
This is a mount for BetaFPV Z1 Camera and VTX system for Beta65/Beta65S tinywhoop-style quadcopters.

There are 2 files - one is a mount for stock Z1 camera-VTX system to put on top of BetaFPV F3 brushed controller. The stock Z1 is when a camera is soldered to VTX with pins/solder pads.

My Z1 didn't last long, and after a dozen of crashes the camera bent, and then separated from the VTX part. The pins and solder pads were ripped off. For this case I designed a second mount - Z1 mount with camera stand. Desolder remainings of metal pins from camera and VTX, then solder small wires (leave some extra, you can trim them later) to camera and VTX pads where pins were, slide camera into the mount. Then solder 5V to 5V wires , GND to GND, and video to video, or to OSD pins on Betafpv flight controller (if you have OSD).

author: ta5jda

description.text:
These are backing disks for protocol droid eyes. Print them with the flat sides down so that you don't need any supports etc.

These are sized for 38mm eyes, but you may need to resize the 3D models depending on the size or type of eye you have. On my helmet the LED assemblies do not contact my eyes but you may need to reduce the depth depending on the LEDs you are using (I am using super bright 5mm 3.6V 20MA LEDs, wired in parallel with 1/4W 47ohm resistors on the positive leads. They are powered by 3AA batteries / 4.5V)

The main disc with the 3 large holes and large center hole (protocol_eye_led_holder.stl)

  • has holes 3 evenly spaced 5mm LEDs
  • the LEDs face outwards
  • the large center hole holes your brass rod for the "pupil" of the eyes
  • once you insert the LED's from behind (flat back side), you bend the LED leads at 90 degrees so they they lie flat. once you solder your LED's and resistors, shrink tubing etc. you can insert the rear cap.

protocol_eye_rear_cap.stl

  • this snaps into place over the BACK of the LED
  • this rear cap prevents the LEDs from blinding the wearer *you may need to cover the rear cap with black tape to ensure no light penetrates the rear cap, since people may print with a different opacity of PLA etc.
  • there are short pins that line up with holes on the LED holder. You may need to drill the holes to clean them up
  • ensure your brass rods can pass all the way through the 2 backing discs, your clear eye lens and make contact with the front eye grills
  • the rear cap can be glued down over the LED holder with CA glue

The entire assembly can be hot glued over your brass or plastic eyes or held in place with epoxy putty, tape etc.

description.text:
These will be of particular interest to anyone who owns a modern motor-home or caravan; glass top panels over sinks and cook-tops rest on these when not in use.

Genuine replacements are nearly impossible to find, and are sold in small lots at extortionate prices. Ideally these should be printed with flexible filament.

Using the following options:

$cable_diameter = 20
$desk_height = 40
$radius_outer_edge = 10
$radius_inner_edge = 5
$width = 20
$wall_thickness = 5
$depth = 70

Clamps that help secure the glass bed from later movement. It also helps keep the heat bed and glass together. I removed 1 spring from each side on the front and added a #4S washer to the top of the spring and used the stock washer on the bottom. Probably can just reuse the stock washer on the top of the spring and it will work.

I know the "washer groves" on the inside of blocks don't do anything as they are on the bottom side of the heatbed, but didn't feel like filling them in. Also, there is some room to tweak the depth of the heatbed grooves to remove the yaw, but they seem to be pretty secure so far in my prints and I'll address that it it becomes an issue.

15 Jan 18
Added V2 of the front two clamps with a hole for the allen wrench to be used to help tighten down the clamps and the nut. Mine had loosened up a little and cause a layer shift during the print. Since I was able to snug them down better. Also, corrected the back right clamp as the second extruder would almost be touching the block, I lowered the right side a little bit more to prevent this.

8 Feb 18
I recommend printing these is something that requires higher temperatures such as ABS or PETG. I printed mine in PLA and noticed the bottoms were warping, especially after printing PETG with the head bed set to 70. I believe this is also causing my clamps to loosen up, but that might be contributed with me trying to get the prints off the glass as they sometimes stick really good.

Printer:

Bibo2 Touch Laser

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.15

comments.text: Very convenient. I was previously using little binder clips along with the normal setup because lets be honest the way it comes is quite bad. This looks way better and holds the glass flatter to the heatbed. Seems to hold well so far, no issues yet. Thanks!!

comments.text: We just printed these to use on our BIBO printer and so far so good! What a great idea! The idea of tension using only bolts when the aluminum plate they are affixed to didn't seem to hold the glass very well and this is the perfect alternative. Thank you so much for these!

comments.text: Glad this worked for you. I just uploaded some tweaks to the front clamps that add the allen key holes so they can be tightened better and the back right was a little too close to the extruder so I lowered the side a little more. You might not need these if everything is working well for you, but I noticed my front clamps loosened up a little and I ended up getting a layer shift during a print.

title: Phone/Camera Attachment for Ikea Lersta floor lamp

description.text: Yes, this is another thing for attaching a camera to an Ikea lamp. This was inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:18781 except rather than replace the lamp, I augment it. It is made to be inserted between the lamp cover/diffuser and the body. Oh, what I've uploaded is slightly modified from the one I'm using... I removed a bunch of extraneous material so it's faster to print (and better for the environment). So it's possible (but unlikely) that this may not work for you! I'll get around to printing the revised version some day... Ikea Lersta: http://www.ikea.com/us/en/catalog/products/20110903/

• Remove the bulb, and unscrew the collar on your lamp. Take off the collar, the middle piece and the cover.

  • Insert the printed object, put everything back and screw the collar back on.

  • Insert a dowel, connect the overjoint, insert another dowel and use something like http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:27458 to hold your phone.

  • Done.
    • Note that Lersta is not designed to handle the weigh and won't hold some positions with this thing attached. I've had the most luck with the phone positioned closer to the tall pole. Pretty sure that the leverage the phone has on the flexible stalk is minimized there.

title: I Can't Believe It's Not Butter!  RunCam 2 -- Tight-box Mount For Skitzo Frames

description.text:
This is a MechaGyver ORIGINAL!

I have seen different RunCam printables and I could not find one that defined one of my favorite builds; the "Skitzo-Dark Matter" by Lumenier. I really enjoy flying FPV, I have been flying for a few years and like most pilots--I crash a LOT. I kept breaking mounts, printing for hours, and I was slowly seeing a pattern of destruction with the mounts I was using.

I came up with this design after seeing where other designs have failed and I hope you like flying at 18-degrees. Ya, this mount was not made for racing and it is more suitable for entry-level flying. I am slowly grinding away on other designs and if there is enough interest in this design I will make some variants.

When all is said and done,

I hope you guys like the design and this is my first time contributing on thingiverse. I am looking forward to all of the feedback that I can get and please leave a comment if you liked the design....that would mean a lot to me.

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Sainte-Mère-Église is a commune in the Manche department in Normandy in northwestern France.

The town's main claim to fame is that it played a significant part in the World War II Normandy landings because this village stood right in the middle of route N13, which the Germans would have most likely used on any significant counterattack on the troops landing on Utah and Omaha Beaches. In the early morning of 6 June 1944 mixed units of the U.S. 82nd Airborne and U.S. 101st Airborne Divisions occupied the town in Mission Boston, giving it the claim to be one of the first towns liberated in the invasion.

AirBlaster fan mount replaces the standard metal fan mount provided for Tronxy X5S in order to increase the cooling efficiency using the out of the box fans.

The top fan cools the plastic as it is being extruded onto the surface using two side ducts which divert airflow towards the extruder nozzle tip. It is also designed with ease in mind as it slides directly into the bottom unit without any screws for easy access to the tube connector if blockages occur or when the plastic filament replacement is required.

The bottom fan is designed to direct air through the extruder heat sink more efficiently by allowing air to pass through the ribs of the heat sink rather than dispersing the air around it.

Observations post printing

Since I installed my unit I had no issues with PLA clogging in the heatsink section which is a big improvement on the standard cooler. The standard cooling unit used to get blocked almost every time inside the heatsink section. This caused clogging of the nylon line that feeds the filament and required me to snip the end 2 times. :)

comments.text: I have done both with and without. Works both ways although its a little better with supports because there are areas where it can droop a little.
comments.author: pinowet

comments.text: Gozz, like the compactness of the design but didn't like the 2 part construction. I've remixed it as a 1 part. I'm happy to remove it if you're not keen or would rather but think others might find the 1 part useful.
comments.author: PTargett

comments.text: If one-part print suits you thats fine with me. Reason I did the 2 parts was mainly because its easier getting to the nylon line behind the fan without having to unscrew the whole thing. As far as the efficiency goes its pretty much the same thing. My printed parts fit together without any issues. This would strictly depend on the quality of prints on individual printers. Having said that i am working on a re-design for it which should work better.
comments.author: PTargett

comments.text: isn't it getting really hot at the side of the hotend?
comments.author: OttoRenner

comments.text: Not at all because I left a sufficient gap between the hot-end and the plastic which prevents it from being melted. Yes the plastic can be warm or softer around it however it should not deform shape if installed on a standard extruder. The hot-end should not be touching the air ducts which are cooling the extruded plastic. Also you have to keep in mind that the ducts are cooled as the air passes though it.
comments.author: OttoRenner

comments.text: To add to the above, if you are still concerned about the plastic being melted you can try to put some kapton tape on the inside part closest to extruder. This should help insulate the ducts form thermal radiation.
comments.author: Gozz

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

normal (0.12)

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Printed this using Ninjaflex (TPU). In Cura settings I enabled Spiralise Outer Contour and Smooth Spiralised Contours. Make sure combing is on. I noticed some strange travels on Cura 3, but Cura 2.7 worked fine. Print should take roughly 20 minutes.

Important settings
nozzle: 0.6
material: TPU 95A
build plate adhesion: brim (8mm)
You might want to have some nail clippers or small scissors handy to cut away the excess material that is created around the two buttonhole overhangs.
